biography:
Sly and the Family Stone were an American rock, funk, and soul band from San Francisco, California. Active from 1966 to 1983, the band was pivotal in the development of soul, funk, and psychedelic music. Headed by singer, songwriter, record producer, and multi-instrumentalist Sly Stone, and containing several of his family members and friends, the band was the first major American rock band to have an "integrated, multi-gender" lineup.
Brothers Sly Stone and singer/guitarist Freddie Stone combined their bands (Sly & the Stoners and Freddie & the Stone Souls) in 1967. Sly and Freddie Stone, trumpeter Cynthia Robinson, drummer Gregg Errico, saxophonist Jerry Martini, and bassist Larry Graham completed the original lineup; Sly and Freddie's sister, singer/keyboardist Rose Stone, joined within a year. This collective recorded five Billboard Hot 100 hits which reached the top 10, and four ground-breaking albums, which greatly influenced the sound of American pop music, soul, R&B, funk, and hip hop music. In the preface of his 1998 book For the Record: Sly and the Family Stone: An Oral History, Joel Selvin sums up the importance of Sly and the Family Stone's influence on African American music by stating "there are two types of black music: black music before Sly Stone, and black music after Sly Stone". The band was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1993.
During the early 1970s, the band switched to a grittier funk sound, which was as influential on the music industry as their earlier work. The band began to fall apart during this period because of drug abuse and ego clashes; consequently, the fortunes and reliability of the band deteriorated, leading to its dissolution in 1975. Sly Stone continued to record albums and tour with a new rotating lineup under the "Sly and the Family Stone" name from 1975 to 1983. In 1987, Sly Stone was arrested and sentenced for cocaine use, after which he went into effective retirement.
name: Sly & The Family Stone

discogs.name: Sly & The Family Stone
namevariations: スライ＆ファミリー・ストーン
discogs.profile:
Formed in San Francisco, CA in November 1966 with members:
Sly Stone (b. Sylvester Stewart, 15th March 1943, Denton, TX - d. 9th June 2025)
Freddie Stone (b. 5th June 1946, Vallejo, CA)
Cynthia Robinson (b. 12th January 1946, Sacramento, CA - d. 23 November 2015 Carmichael, CA)
Jerry Martini (b. 1st October 1943, Denver CO)
Larry Graham (b. 14th August 1946, Beaumont, TX)
Greg Errico (b. 1st September 1946, San Francisco, CA)
Rosie Stone (b. 21st March 1945, Vallejo, CA) (joined the original group in January 1968)

Inducted into Rock And Roll Hall of Fame in 1993 (Performer).

theaudiodb.biography_en:
Sly and the Family Stone were an American rock, funk, and soul band from San Francisco, California. Active from 1966 to 1983, the band was pivotal in the development of soul, funk, and psychedelic music. Headed by singer, songwriter, record producer, and multi-instrumentalist Sly Stone, and containing several of his family members and friends, the band was the first major American rock band to have an "integrated, multi-gender" lineup.
Brothers Sly Stone and singer/guitarist Freddie Stone combined their bands (Sly & the Stoners and Freddie & the Stone Souls) in 1967. Sly and Freddie Stone, trumpeter Cynthia Robinson, drummer Gregg Errico, saxophonist Jerry Martini, and bassist Larry Graham completed the original lineup; Sly and Freddie's sister, singer/keyboardist Rose Stone, joined within a year. This collective recorded five Billboard Hot 100 hits which reached the top 10, and four ground-breaking albums, which greatly influenced the sound of American pop music, soul, R&B, funk, and hip hop music. In the preface of his 1998 book For the Record: Sly and the Family Stone: An Oral History, Joel Selvin sums up the importance of Sly and the Family Stone's influence on African American music by stating "there are two types of black music: black music before Sly Stone, and black music after Sly Stone". The band was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1993.
During the early 1970s, the band switched to a grittier funk sound, which was as influential on the music industry as their earlier work. The band began to fall apart during this period because of drug abuse and ego clashes; consequently, the fortunes and reliability of the band deteriorated, leading to its dissolution in 1975. Sly Stone continued to record albums and tour with a new rotating lineup under the "Sly and the Family Stone" name from 1975 to 1983. In 1987, Sly Stone was arrested and sentenced for cocaine use, after which he went into effective retirement.
theaudiodb.biography_es:
Sly and the Family Stone fue una banda estadounidense de rock, funk y soul de San Francisco, California. Activa desde 1966 hasta 1983, la banda fue fundamental en el desarrollo de la música soul, funk y psicodélica. Encabezada por el cantante, compositor, productor de discos y multiinstrumentista Sly Stone, y con varios miembros de su familia y amigos, la banda fue la primera banda de rock estadounidense importante en tener una formación "integrada y multigénero".
Los hermanos Sly Stone y el cantante y guitarrista Freddie Stone combinaron sus bandas (Sly & the Stoners y Freddie & the Stone Souls) en 1967. Sly y Freddie Stone, la trompetista Cynthia Robinson, el baterista Gregg Errico, el saxofonista Jerry Martini y el bajista Larry Graham completaron la formación original; La hermana de Sly y Freddie, la cantante y teclista Rose Stone, se unió al año. Este colectivo grabó cinco éxitos de Billboard Hot 100 que llegaron al top 10 y cuatro álbumes innovadores que influyeron mucho en el sonido de la música pop estadounidense, el soul, el R&B, el funk y el hip hop. En el prefacio de su libro de 1998 For the Record: Sly and the Family Stone: An Oral History, Joel Selvin resume la importancia de la influencia de Sly and the Family Stone en la música afroamericana al afirmar que "hay dos tipos de música negra: música negra música antes de Sly Stone y música negra después de Sly Stone". La banda fue incluida en el Salón de la Fama del Rock and Roll en 1993.
A principios de la década de 1970, la banda cambió a un sonido funk más arenoso, que fue tan influyente en la industria de la música como su trabajo anterior. La banda comenzó a desmoronarse durante este período debido al abuso de drogas y los choques de ego; en consecuencia, la fortuna y la confiabilidad de la banda se deterioraron, lo que llevó a su disolución en 1975. Sly Stone continuó grabando álbumes y haciendo giras con una nueva formación rotativa bajo el nombre de "Sly and the Family Stone" de 1975 a 1983. En 1987, Sly Stone fue arrestado y sentenciado por consumo de cocaína, luego de lo cual se retiró efectivamente.
theaudiodb.biography_fr:
Sly and the Family Stone est un groupe américain de rock, de funk et de soul originaire de San Francisco, en Californie. 
Actif de 1966 à 1983, le groupe a joué un rôle central dans le développement de la musique soul, funk et psychédélique. Dirigé par le chanteur, auteur-compositeur, producteur de disques et multi-instrumentiste Sly Stone, et comprenant plusieurs membres de sa famille et amis.
Les frères Sly Stone et le chanteur/guitariste Freddie Stone ont réuni leurs groupes (Sly & the Stoners et Freddie & the Stone Souls) en 1967. La trompettiste Cynthia Robinson, le batteur Gregg Errico, le saxophoniste Jerry Martini et le bassiste Larry Graham complètent la formation d'origine ; la sœur de Sly et Freddie, la chanteuse et claviériste Rose Stone, les rejoint un an plus tard.
Ce collectif a enregistré cinq tubes du Billboard Hot 100 qui ont atteint le top 10, et quatre albums révolutionnaires qui ont grandement influencé le son de la musique pop américaine, de la soul, du R&B, du funk et du hip-hop.
Dans la préface de son livre "For the Record : Sly and the Family Stone : An Oral History", Joel Selvin résume l'importance de l'influence de Sly and the Family Stone sur la musique afro-américaine en déclarant "il y a deux types de musique noire : la musique noire avant Sly Stone, et la musique noire après Sly Stone". Le groupe a été intronisé au Rock and Roll Hall of Fame en 1993.
Au début des années 1970, le groupe est passé à un son funk plus brut, qui a eu autant d'influence sur l'industrie musicale que leur travail précédent. Au cours de cette période, le groupe a commencé à se désagréger en raison de l'abus de drogues et de conflits internes. La fortune et la fiabilité du groupe se détériorant, il est dissout en 1975. Sly Stone a continué à enregistrer des albums et à faire des tournées avec une nouvelle formation tournante sous le nom de "Sly and the Family Stone" de 1975 à 1983. En 1987, Sly Stone a été arrêté et condamné pour usage de cocaïne, après quoi il prend sa retraite.

discogs.name: Sly & The Family Stone
namevariations: スライ＆ファミリー・ストーン
discogs.profile:
Formed in San Francisco, CA in November 1966 with members:
Sly Stone (b. Sylvester Stewart, 15th March 1943, Denton, TX - d. 9th June 2025)
Freddie Stone (b. 5th June 1946, Vallejo, CA)
Cynthia Robinson (b. 12th January 1946, Sacramento, CA - d. 23 November 2015 Carmichael, CA)
Jerry Martini (b. 1st October 1943, Denver CO)
Larry Graham (b. 14th August 1946, Beaumont, TX)
Greg Errico (b. 1st September 1946, San Francisco, CA)
Rosie Stone (b. 21st March 1945, Vallejo, CA) (joined the original group in January 1968)

Inducted into Rock And Roll Hall of Fame in 1993 (Performer).

lastfm.bio_content: Sly & the Family Stone were a band from Vallejo, California, United States. Active from 1966 until 1975, the band was pivotal in the development of soul, funk and psychedelia. Headed by singer, songwriter, record producer, and multi-instrumentalist Sly Stone, and containing several of his family members and friends, the band was the first major American rock band to have an integrated lineup in both race and gender. Brothers Sly Stone and singer/guitarist Freddie Stone combined their bands (Sly & the Stoners and Freddie & the Stone Souls) at the end of 1966. Sly and Freddie Stone, trumpeter Cynthia Robinson, drummer Gregg Errico, saxophonist Jerry Martini, and bassist Larry Graham completed the original lineup; Sly and Freddie's sister, singer/keyboardist Rose Stone, joined within a year. This collective recorded five Top 10 hits and four groundbreaking albums, which greatly influenced the sound of American pop music, soul, R&B, funk, and hip hop music. In the preface of his 1998 book For the Record: Sly and the Family Stone: An Oral History, Joel Selvin sums up the importance of Sly & the Family Stone's influence on African American music by stating "there are two types of black music: black music before Sly Stone, and black music after Sly Stone". The band was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1993. During the early 1970s, the band switched to a grittier funk sound, which was as influential on the music industry as their earlier work. The band began to fall apart during this period because of drug abuse and ego clashes; consequently, the fortunes and reliability of the band deteriorated, leading to its dissolution in 1975. Sly Stone continued to record albums and tour with a new rotating lineup under the "Sly & the Family Stone" name from 1975 to 1983. In 1987, Sly Stone was arrested and sentenced for cocaine use, after which he went into effective retirement. Sly Stone passed away on June 9th at the age of 82. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

Headed by singer, songwriter, record producer, and multi-instrumentalist Sly Stone, and containing several of his family members and friends, the band was the first major American rock band to have an integrated lineup in both race and gender. Brothers Sly Stone and singer/guitarist Read more on Last.fm

theaudiodb.biography_en:
Sly and the Family Stone were an American rock, funk, and soul band from San Francisco, California. Active from 1966 to 1983, the band was pivotal in the development of soul, funk, and psychedelic music. Headed by singer, songwriter, record producer, and multi-instrumentalist Sly Stone, and containing several of his family members and friends, the band was the first major American rock band to have an "integrated, multi-gender" lineup.
Brothers Sly Stone and singer/guitarist Freddie Stone combined their bands (Sly & the Stoners and Freddie & the Stone Souls) in 1967. Sly and Freddie Stone, trumpeter Cynthia Robinson, drummer Gregg Errico, saxophonist Jerry Martini, and bassist Larry Graham completed the original lineup; Sly and Freddie's sister, singer/keyboardist Rose Stone, joined within a year. This collective recorded five Billboard Hot 100 hits which reached the top 10, and four ground-breaking albums, which greatly influenced the sound of American pop music, soul, R&B, funk, and hip hop music. In the preface of his 1998 book For the Record: Sly and the Family Stone: An Oral History, Joel Selvin sums up the importance of Sly and the Family Stone's influence on African American music by stating "there are two types of black music: black music before Sly Stone, and black music after Sly Stone". The band was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1993.
During the early 1970s, the band switched to a grittier funk sound, which was as influential on the music industry as their earlier work. The band began to fall apart during this period because of drug abuse and ego clashes; consequently, the fortunes and reliability of the band deteriorated, leading to its dissolution in 1975. Sly Stone continued to record albums and tour with a new rotating lineup under the "Sly and the Family Stone" name from 1975 to 1983. In 1987, Sly Stone was arrested and sentenced for cocaine use, after which he went into effective retirement.
theaudiodb.biography_es:
Sly and the Family Stone fue una banda estadounidense de rock, funk y soul de San Francisco, California. Activa desde 1966 hasta 1983, la banda fue fundamental en el desarrollo de la música soul, funk y psicodélica. Encabezada por el cantante, compositor, productor de discos y multiinstrumentista Sly Stone, y con varios miembros de su familia y amigos, la banda fue la primera banda de rock estadounidense importante en tener una formación "integrada y multigénero".
Los hermanos Sly Stone y el cantante y guitarrista Freddie Stone combinaron sus bandas (Sly & the Stoners y Freddie & the Stone Souls) en 1967. Sly y Freddie Stone, la trompetista Cynthia Robinson, el baterista Gregg Errico, el saxofonista Jerry Martini y el bajista Larry Graham completaron la formación original; La hermana de Sly y Freddie, la cantante y teclista Rose Stone, se unió al año. Este colectivo grabó cinco éxitos de Billboard Hot 100 que llegaron al top 10 y cuatro álbumes innovadores que influyeron mucho en el sonido de la música pop estadounidense, el soul, el R&B, el funk y el hip hop. En el prefacio de su libro de 1998 For the Record: Sly and the Family Stone: An Oral History, Joel Selvin resume la importancia de la influencia de Sly and the Family Stone en la música afroamericana al afirmar que "hay dos tipos de música negra: música negra música antes de Sly Stone y música negra después de Sly Stone". La banda fue incluida en el Salón de la Fama del Rock and Roll en 1993.
A principios de la década de 1970, la banda cambió a un sonido funk más arenoso, que fue tan influyente en la industria de la música como su trabajo anterior. La banda comenzó a desmoronarse durante este período debido al abuso de drogas y los choques de ego; en consecuencia, la fortuna y la confiabilidad de la banda se deterioraron, lo que llevó a su disolución en 1975. Sly Stone continuó grabando álbumes y haciendo giras con una nueva formación rotativa bajo el nombre de "Sly and the Family Stone" de 1975 a 1983. En 1987, Sly Stone fue arrestado y sentenciado por consumo de cocaína, luego de lo cual se retiró efectivamente.
